item.title: Scaling the World's Largest Django Application
item.blip:puredescription: Disqus, one of the largest Django applications in the world, will explain how they deal with scaling complexities in a small startup.
item.description: Disqus, one of the largest Django applications in the world, will explain how they deal with scaling complexities in a small startup.

item.media:title: Sprints Kickoff

item.title: Multi-database patterns
item.blip:puredescription: A tour through four common "multiple database" usage patterns and how they can be implemented and utilised with Django. We'll talk about the strengths and weaknesses of each pattern and why you might not need any of them.
item.description: A tour through four common "multiple database" usage patterns and how they can be implemented and utilised with Django. We'll talk about the strengths and weaknesses of each pattern and why you might not need any of them.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH9wRIC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Multi-database patterns

item.title: Massaging the Pony: Message Queues and You
item.blip:puredescription: Message queues are a potential solution for any site that needs to facilitate robust asynchronous operations on your website including carrying out intensive or long-running actions or synchronizing off-site services. We will look at how PBS has used Celery and RabbitMQ to provide more reliable service and how to set up a robust message queue solution in a cloud hosting environment.
item.description: Message queues are a potential solution for any site that needs to facilitate robust asynchronous operations on your website including carrying out intensive or long-running actions or synchronizing off-site services. We will look at how PBS has used Celery and RabbitMQ to provide more reliable service and how to set up a robust message queue solution in a cloud hosting environment.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH9v1MC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Massaging the Pony: Message Queues and You

item.title: Learning a new codebase
item.blip:puredescription: This talk will be on methods of reading code for comprehension. While the project will be walking through various third-party Django apps, the experiences and conclusions are drawn from joining a large, existing Django project which lacked documentation.
item.description: This talk will be on methods of reading code for comprehension. While the project will be walking through various third-party Django apps, the experiences and conclusions are drawn from joining a large, existing Django project which lacked documentation.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH9vjoC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Learning a new codebase

item.title: Alice in Performanceland -- Down the Rabbit Hole with Frank Wiles
item.blip:puredescription: While pre-optimization is often the root of all evil, knowing how to think about performance and scalability are important skills for any geek. Learn about all the knobs you didn't know you could or should tweak.
item.description: While pre-optimization is often the root of all evil, knowing how to think about performance and scalability are important skills for any geek. Learn about all the knobs you didn't know you could or should tweak.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH9vSYC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Alice in Performanceland -- Down the Rabbit Hole with Frank Wiles

item.title: Modeling challenges
item.blip:puredescription: How would you model players, umpires and coaches in baseball data when the same person can switch roles over the course of their life? How about servers in racks with power boards attached (and cords running across the room to remote boards)? Come along to see one approach to create minimal and well-performing models for such real-life situations.
item.description: How would you model players, umpires and coaches in baseball data when the same person can switch roles over the course of their life? How about servers in racks with power boards attached (and cords running across the room to remote boards)? Come along to see one approach to create minimal and well-performing models for such real-life situations.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH9pBQC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Modeling challenges

item.title: Technical Design Panel
item.blip:puredescription: Come one! Come all! Pay sixpence to see the freaks! Real Live Core Developers, answering questions for your edification!
item.description: Come one! Come all! Pay sixpence to see the freaks! Real Live Core Developers, answering questions for your edification!
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH8mEcC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Technical Design Panel

item.title: Why Django Sucks, and How We Can Fix It
item.blip:puredescription: Eric Florenzano trolls DjangoCon. He identifies problems with Django ranging from app structure, to settings, to the development process, to the community, and more. Some of the problems he identifies have been around since the beginning, and some are emerging as Django matures. It's not all gloom—the latter half of the talk focuses on proposals on how to tackle these issues that face Django.
item.description: Eric Florenzano trolls DjangoCon. He identifies problems with Django ranging from app structure, to settings, to the development process, to the community, and more. Some of the problems he identifies have been around since the beginning, and some are emerging as Django matures. It's not all gloom—the latter half of the talk focuses on proposals on how to tackle these issues that face Django.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH8lEsC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Why Django Sucks, and How We Can Fix It

item.title: Topics of Interest
item.blip:puredescription: Inspired by Ian Bicking's session of the same name at PyCon 2009, this will be a somewhat eclectic talk covering various subjects near and dear to the speaker's heart, including Django's release process, best practices for application development and what the future holds for our favorite Python web framework.
item.description: Inspired by Ian Bicking's session of the same name at PyCon 2009, this will be a somewhat eclectic talk covering various subjects near and dear to the speaker's heart, including Django's release process, best practices for application development and what the future holds for our favorite Python web framework.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH8kgQC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>

item.title: Data Herding: How to Shepherd Your Flock Through Valleys of Darkness
item.blip:puredescription: Learn how to use common tools like the management shell, django-extensions, and iPython to craft an effective workflow whether you're building a new schema or migrating from old systems. We'll also look at how to take advantage of the latest ORM features.
item.description: Learn how to use common tools like the management shell, django-extensions, and iPython to craft an effective workflow whether you're building a new schema or migrating from old systems. We'll also look at how to take advantage of the latest ORM features.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH7_GMC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>

item.title: Monitoring Code Quality in Your Django Project
item.blip:puredescription: Using tools such as Pylint, Nose, and Coverage.py with the Hudson continuous integration server to monitor your code quality. (Video incomplete)
item.description: Using tools such as Pylint, Nose, and Coverage.py with the Hudson continuous integration server to monitor your code quality. (Video incomplete)

item.media:title: Monitoring Code Quality in Your Django Project

item.title: Alternative views
item.blip:puredescription: Exploring the power of class-based views, their current status and how the concepts behind them can be applied to other areas.
item.description: Exploring the power of class-based views, their current status and how the concepts behind them can be applied to other areas.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH7%2B18C" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Alternative views

item.title: Treehugging
item.blip:puredescription: Hierarchical data sprouts up almost everywhere, but not all trees look alike. Learn to how tell them apart and love them all in Django.
item.description: Hierarchical data sprouts up almost everywhere, but not all trees look alike. Learn to how tell them apart and love them all in Django.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH7%2BD8C" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Treehugging

item.title: Rethinking the Reusable Application Paradigm
item.blip:puredescription: For the past few years the reusable application paradigm has been considered one of the major selling points of Django, however the common wisdom about what it means to make an application reusable isn't really accurate. This talk is going to discuss ways to truly make your applications reusable across *any* project.
item.description: For the past few years the reusable application paradigm has been considered one of the major selling points of Django, however the common wisdom about what it means to make an application reusable isn't really accurate. This talk is going to discuss ways to truly make your applications reusable across *any* project.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH793QC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Rethinking the Reusable Application Paradigm

item.title: Large Problems in Django, Mostly Solved
item.blip:puredescription: This talk is based on my popular series of blog posts highlighting applications from the community. I will highlight some of the best applications that the Django/Python community has put together, talk about places that are lacking, and talk about what these popular applications have in common.
item.description: This talk is based on my popular series of blog posts highlighting applications from the community. I will highlight some of the best applications that the Django/Python community has put together, talk about places that are lacking, and talk about what these popular applications have in common.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH76j8C" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Large Problems in Django, Mostly Solved

item.title: How to sell Django
item.blip:puredescription: It seems that a lot of people want to use Django (and Python), but their customer, management, or organization won't let them. Django is a great tool, but it can be challenging to get in the door. This panel will explore how companies and individuals have successfully introduced Django, what tools are available to sell Django, and what pitfalls there are to avoid.
item.description: It seems that a lot of people want to use Django (and Python), but their customer, management, or organization won't let them. Django is a great tool, but it can be challenging to get in the door. This panel will explore how companies and individuals have successfully introduced Django, what tools are available to sell Django, and what pitfalls there are to avoid.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH76hgC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: How to sell Django

item.title: Domain Specific Frameworks - Why they rock and what can we do to get more of them
item.blip:puredescription: This talk will provide an overview of some of the existing domain specific frameworks (DSFs) in the Python/Django world, review some of the common patterns used within them, and then explore some things which can be done to make it easier for people to create and maintain DSFs.
item.description: This talk will provide an overview of some of the existing domain specific frameworks (DSFs) in the Python/Django world, review some of the common patterns used within them, and then explore some things which can be done to make it easier for people to create and maintain DSFs.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH76XgC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="390" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Domain Specific Frameworks - Why they rock and what can we do to get more of them

item.title: State of Pinax
item.blip:puredescription: Pinax is a platform for rapidly building websites with Django. This talk will cover what has happened with Pinax over the past year and where it will go in the future.
item.description: Pinax is a platform for rapidly building websites with Django. This talk will cover what has happened with Pinax over the past year and where it will go in the future.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH76VkC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="390" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: State of Pinax

item.title: Customizing the Django Admin
item.blip:puredescription: How to build great admin user interfaces while still leveraging the power of the Django's batteries-included admin.
item.description: How to build great admin user interfaces while still leveraging the power of the Django's batteries-included admin.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH76SUC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Customizing the Django Admin

item.title: First steps in performance tuning
item.blip:puredescription: So you've built your first Django website. You've tested it, you've released it, you've got a few customers... and a few more... and a few more... and now you're having performance problems. What do you do? This talk will look at some performance problems you may experience, and show some simple (and creative) ways to squeeze the most out of your server hardware.
item.description: So you've built your first Django website. You've tested it, you've released it, you've got a few customers... and a few more... and a few more... and now you're having performance problems. What do you do? This talk will look at some performance problems you may experience, and show some simple (and creative) ways to squeeze the most out of your server hardware.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH76HoC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: First steps in performance tuning

item.title: Pony Pwning
item.blip:puredescription: Django's awesomeness unfortunately doesn't make it impenetrable. This talk will cover common pitfalls of the Django developer as seen through the eyes of a hacker or malicious user.
item.description: Django's awesomeness unfortunately doesn't make it impenetrable. This talk will cover common pitfalls of the Django developer as seen through the eyes of a hacker or malicious user.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH76EQC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Pony Pwning

item.title: Switching addons.mozilla.org from CakePHP to Django
item.blip:puredescription: In January of 2010 Mozilla started switching addons.mozilla.org (AMO) from CakePHP to Django. We see about 120 million web requests per month and 1.4 million visitors per day. This talk will be a case study of scaling and deploying a large website (and getting faster than PHP) with MySQL, memcached, virtualenv, Celery, Hudson, Redis, MongoDB, and more.
item.description: In January of 2010 Mozilla started switching addons.mozilla.org (AMO) from CakePHP to Django. We see about 120 million web requests per month and 1.4 million visitors per day. This talk will be a case study of scaling and deploying a large website (and getting faster than PHP) with MySQL, memcached, virtualenv, Celery, Hudson, Redis, MongoDB, and more.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH76AkC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="390" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Switching addons.mozilla.org from CakePHP to Django

item.title: Django Forms: Tips, Tricks and Ways to Stay Out of Trouble
item.blip:puredescription: As a Django novice, one challenge is understanding the full depth and power of the core Django modules. At PBS we have found that leveraging the features of Django's Forms module helps us create better code that is easy to maintain and facilitates future enhancements to our sites. This presentation will discuss some often overlooked features of Forms, helpful tips, and potential pitfalls.
item.description: As a Django novice, one challenge is understanding the full depth and power of the core Django modules. At PBS we have found that leveraging the features of Django's Forms module helps us create better code that is easy to maintain and facilitates future enhancements to our sites. This presentation will discuss some often overlooked features of Forms, helpful tips, and potential pitfalls.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH751wC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="390" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Django Forms: Tips, Tricks and Ways to Stay Out of Trouble

item.title: Maps of Imaginary Lands
item.blip:puredescription: The GIS features of Django aren't restricted to being applied to real world maps and planets. This talk will show how to display and interact with maps of imaginary lands, such as game maps or lands in science fiction novels. We'll uncover a bit of how Django GIS works in the process, separating the map display from the modeling.
item.description: The GIS features of Django aren't restricted to being applied to real world maps and planets. This talk will show how to display and interact with maps of imaginary lands, such as game maps or lands in science fiction novels. We'll uncover a bit of how Django GIS works in the process, separating the map display from the modeling.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH75zEC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="390" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Maps of Imaginary Lands

item.title: Breaking down the process of building a custom CMS
item.blip:puredescription: The purpose of this talk is to share some of the important insights gained over a couple years of working on custom CMS-type projects serving large organizations. Acknowledging that approx. 30 minutes is a short time to cover a broad subject, the focus of the talk would be on outlining a basic strategy for managing large projects.
item.description: The purpose of this talk is to share some of the important insights gained over a couple years of working on custom CMS-type projects serving large organizations. Acknowledging that approx. 30 minutes is a short time to cover a broad subject, the focus of the talk would be on outlining a basic strategy for managing large projects.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH75wcC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Breaking down the process of building a custom CMS

item.title: So you want to be a core developer?
item.blip:puredescription: The most important part of Django is it's community of contributors -- without contributors, Django would never improve. However, as a newcomer to Django, the prospect of contributing may be somewhat daunting. This presentation will show you how to make the transition from user to contributor -- what to do, how to do it, and some guidelines on how to do the job well.
item.description: The most important part of Django is it's community of contributors -- without contributors, Django would never improve. However, as a newcomer to Django, the prospect of contributing may be somewhat daunting. This presentation will show you how to make the transition from user to contributor -- what to do, how to do it, and some guidelines on how to do the job well.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH75jsC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="390" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: So you want to be a core developer?

item.title: DSF Announcements and Q&A
item.blip:puredescription: The Django software foundation is the entity which hold the IP for django and guides efforts to develop the community around Django. In this session several members of the DSF will be announcing some changes at the DSF and will be available for a general Q&A.
item.description: The Django software foundation is the entity which hold the IP for django and guides efforts to develop the community around Django. In this session several members of the DSF will be announcing some changes at the DSF and will be available for a general Q&A.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH75X8C" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="390" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: DSF Announcements and Q&A

item.title: Typewar: A Case Study
item.blip:puredescription: Typewar is a popular font-guessing game built with Django and Pinax. This talk will cover everything from game mechanics and statistics to development of an API for an iPhone client and from how we promoted and launched the site to the performance challenges we faced.
item.description: Typewar is a popular font-guessing game built with Django and Pinax. This talk will cover everything from game mechanics and statistics to development of an API for an iPhone client and from how we promoted and launched the site to the performance challenges we faced.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH75VoC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="414" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Typewar: A Case Study

item.title: Teaching an Old Pony New Tricks: Maintaining and Updating an Aging Django Project
item.blip:puredescription: PBS began development on its first Django project in 2006 using Django 0.96. PBS TeacherLine launched in 2007 and continues to run today. This talk will discuss the process for designing the PBS TeacherLine codebase, how new advanced features were added over the years, and pitfalls you can avoid when planning projects for longevity and easy maintenance.
item.description: PBS began development on its first Django project in 2006 using Django 0.96. PBS TeacherLine launched in 2007 and continues to run today. This talk will discuss the process for designing the PBS TeacherLine codebase, how new advanced features were added over the years, and pitfalls you can avoid when planning projects for longevity and easy maintenance.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AYH75SsC" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="480" height="390" wmode="transparent" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" ></embed>
item.media:title: Teaching an Old Pony New Tricks: Maintaining and Updating an Aging Django Project
